response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The measure has been amended, changing the Accessory Dwelling Unit Financing and Deed Restriction Program from a grant program to an equity purchase program (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The purpose is still to finance the construction of accessory dwelling units, but the mechanism for state investment has shifted. The program is now set to sunset on December 31, 2030 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "appropriations": "The source of funding for the program has been changed from the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund to the Rental Housing Revolving Fund (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt) per year for the program between all counties. The measure now authorizes the counties to use an unspecified percentage of awarded funds for administrative costs (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The methodology has been changed from a grant to an equity purchase model, which allows \"the State to recover on its investment\" (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). A homeowner participating in the program is required to repay HHFDC its prorated share of the appraised value of the completed ADU, with appreciation, within fifteen years or upon sale, whichever occurs first (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The total contribution amount from a county per ADU shall not exceed eight percent of the appraised value of the property (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "agency_impact": "In response to concerns about county liability, the measure was amended to expand the terms of the required indemnification agreement to include the counties and county officers, agents, and employees (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). To address the Department of Taxation's request, the exemption to the Conveyance Tax has been clarified to apply to taxable years beginning January 1, 2026 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). HHFDC is now required to submit a report to the Legislature evaluating the program prior to the Regular Session of 2031 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "economic_impact": "By changing the program to an equity purchase model with a repayment requirement, the state will be able to recover its investment, \"thereby enabling the State to finance additional ADUs in the future\" (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). This shift creates a mechanism to recycle funds and maximize future housing construction with the same initial investment. The program is now also required to prioritize homeowners or homebuyers and prospective tenants that are government employees (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "policy_impact": "The measure has been substantially amended, changing the program from a grant to an equity purchase program and shifting the funding source to the Rental Housing Revolving Fund (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). A sunset date of December 31, 2030, has been added, and the effective date has been changed to July 1, 2050, to encourage further discussion (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The indemnification agreement has been expanded to protect county employees, addressing a key concern from prior testimony (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "revenue_sources": "The funding source for the program has been changed to the Rental Housing Revolving Fund (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). A significant change is the creation of a revenue stream back to the state; under the new equity purchase model, a homeowner must repay HHFDC its prorated share of the property's appraised value, with appreciation, within fifteen years or upon sale (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). This allows the state to \"share in the capital gain of units receiving state funds\" (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The six-year outlook for the program is now more defined due to recent amendments. The program has a funding cap where the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt) per year among all counties. A sunset date of December 31, 2030, has been established, limiting the program's duration and future fiscal commitments (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). A new requirement for homeowners to repay the state's investment within fifteen years or upon sale means that funds expended during the program's operation are expected to be recovered over the long term (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The measure now requires HHFDC to submit a report evaluating the program to the Legislature before the 2031 regular session, which will inform future fiscal decisions (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The concern about perpetual deed restrictions has been addressed by the sunset provision.",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The change from a grant to an equity purchase program introduces a new source of operating revenue for the state. The state will now recover its investment and a \"prorated share of the appraised value of the completed accessory dwelling unit, with appreciation\" (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). This repayment, due within fifteen years or upon sale of the property, will return funds to the state, unlike the previous grant-based proposal (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The state's capital outlay is now structured as a recoverable investment rather than a one-time grant. The total annual capital expenditure for the program is capped, as HHFDC shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt) per year. The nature of the expenditure is an equity purchase that will be repaid to the state with appreciation over time (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The fiscal implications after six years are significantly altered by the introduction of a sunset date of December 31, 2030, which ends the program (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). Instead of perpetual administrative duties, the primary fiscal activity will be the collection of repayments from homeowners, which must occur within fifteen years of the investment or upon property sale (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). This creates an ongoing revenue stream for the state that extends beyond the program's operational period.",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This measure has been significantly amended, changing the funding mechanism from a grant to an equity purchase program, which allows the state to recover its investment with appreciation. The funding source has been switched from the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund to the Rental Housing Revolving Fund, with an annual allocation cap of $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). Key concerns from previous testimony have been addressed by adding a program sunset date of December 31, 2030, and expanding the indemnification agreement to include county officers and employees (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt)."
}

parts.text:
{
  "overview": "The measure has been amended, changing the Accessory Dwelling Unit Financing and Deed Restriction Program from a grant program to an equity purchase program (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The purpose is still to finance the construction of accessory dwelling units, but the mechanism for state investment has shifted. The program is now set to sunset on December 31, 2030 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "appropriations": "The source of funding for the program has been changed from the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund to the Rental Housing Revolving Fund (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt) per year for the program between all counties. The measure now authorizes the counties to use an unspecified percentage of awarded funds for administrative costs (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The methodology has been changed from a grant to an equity purchase model, which allows \"the State to recover on its investment\" (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). A homeowner participating in the program is required to repay HHFDC its prorated share of the appraised value of the completed ADU, with appreciation, within fifteen years or upon sale, whichever occurs first (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The total contribution amount from a county per ADU shall not exceed eight percent of the appraised value of the property (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "agency_impact": "In response to concerns about county liability, the measure was amended to expand the terms of the required indemnification agreement to include the counties and county officers, agents, and employees (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). To address the Department of Taxation's request, the exemption to the Conveyance Tax has been clarified to apply to taxable years beginning January 1, 2026 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). HHFDC is now required to submit a report to the Legislature evaluating the program prior to the Regular Session of 2031 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "economic_impact": "By changing the program to an equity purchase model with a repayment requirement, the state will be able to recover its investment, \"thereby enabling the State to finance additional ADUs in the future\" (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). This shift creates a mechanism to recycle funds and maximize future housing construction with the same initial investment. The program is now also required to prioritize homeowners or homebuyers and prospective tenants that are government employees (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "policy_impact": "The measure has been substantially amended, changing the program from a grant to an equity purchase program and shifting the funding source to the Rental Housing Revolving Fund (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). A sunset date of December 31, 2030, has been added, and the effective date has been changed to July 1, 2050, to encourage further discussion (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The indemnification agreement has been expanded to protect county employees, addressing a key concern from prior testimony (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "revenue_sources": "The funding source for the program has been changed to the Rental Housing Revolving Fund (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). A significant change is the creation of a revenue stream back to the state; under the new equity purchase model, a homeowner must repay HHFDC its prorated share of the property's appraised value, with appreciation, within fifteen years or upon sale (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). This allows the state to \"share in the capital gain of units receiving state funds\" (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The six-year outlook for the program is now more defined due to recent amendments. The program has a funding cap where the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt) per year among all counties. A sunset date of December 31, 2030, has been established, limiting the program's duration and future fiscal commitments (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). A new requirement for homeowners to repay the state's investment within fifteen years or upon sale means that funds expended during the program's operation are expected to be recovered over the long term (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The measure now requires HHFDC to submit a report evaluating the program to the Legislature before the 2031 regular session, which will inform future fiscal decisions (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). The concern about perpetual deed restrictions has been addressed by the sunset provision.",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The change from a grant to an equity purchase program introduces a new source of operating revenue for the state. The state will now recover its investment and a \"prorated share of the appraised value of the completed accessory dwelling unit, with appreciation\" (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). This repayment, due within fifteen years or upon sale of the property, will return funds to the state, unlike the previous grant-based proposal (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The state's capital outlay is now structured as a recoverable investment rather than a one-time grant. The total annual capital expenditure for the program is capped, as HHFDC shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt) per year. The nature of the expenditure is an equity purchase that will be repaid to the state with appreciation over time (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt).",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The fiscal implications after six years are significantly altered by the introduction of a sunset date of December 31, 2030, which ends the program (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). Instead of perpetual administrative duties, the primary fiscal activity will be the collection of repayments from homeowners, which must occur within fifteen years of the investment or upon property sale (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). This creates an ongoing revenue stream for the state that extends beyond the program's operational period.",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "This measure has been significantly amended, changing the funding mechanism from a grant to an equity purchase program, which allows the state to recover its investment with appreciation. The funding source has been switched from the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund to the Rental Housing Revolving Fund, with an annual allocation cap of $2,000,000 (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt). Key concerns from previous testimony have been addressed by adding a program sunset date of December 31, 2030, and expanding the indemnification agreement to include county officers and employees (HB740_SD1_.HTM.txt)."
}

chunk_details.chunk_text: JOSH GREEN, M.D. GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. GOVERNOR DEAN MINAKAMI EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR STATE OF HAWAII DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND TOURISM HAWAII HOUSING FINANCE AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION 677 QUEEN STREET, SUITE 300 HONOLULU, HAWAII 96813 FAX: (808) 587-0600 Statement of DEAN MINAKAMI Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation Before

of DEAN MINAKAMI Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation Before the SENATE COMMITTEE ON HOUSING March 11, 2025 at 1:10 p.m. State Capitol, Room 225 In consideration of H.B. 740 HD2 RELATING TO HOUSING Chair Chang, Vice Chair Hashimoto, and members of the Committee. HHFDC supports HB 740 HD2, which

members of the Committee. HHFDC supports HB 740 HD2, which establishes the Accessory Dwelling Unit (ADU) Financing and Deed Restriction Program to allocate funds to the counties to provide grants to eligible homeowners or homebuyers to finance construction costs, development costs, and non-reoccurring closing costs associated with the construction of

costs, and non-reoccurring closing costs associated with the construction of an ADU and purchase deed restrictions on such property. The upfront costs of designing and permitting an ADU are barriers for many homeowners. HHFDC supports the ADU Financing and Deed Restriction program as a way to increase the inventory of

Restriction program as a way to increase the inventory of rental units in the State. In addition, the deed restriction program will create an inventory of homes for local residents, stabilize home prices, and reduce speculation in our housing market. Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill.

Thank you for the opportunity to testify on this bill. TESTIMONY IN SUPPORT OF HB740 HD2 RELATING TO HOUSING Senate Committee on Housing March 11th, 2025 1:10 p.m. Room 225 Aloha e Chair Chang, Vice Chair Hashimoto, members of the committee: The Office of Hawaiian Affairs (OHA) submits this testimony

committee: The Office of Hawaiian Affairs (OHA) submits this testimony in SUPPORT of HB740 HD2, which would establish an accessory dwelling unit (ADU) financing and deed restriction program under the Hawaiâ€™i Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC). This inventive measure will provide funding for counties to assist eligible homeowners or

will provide funding for counties to assist eligible homeowners or homebuyers with financing the construction of accessory dwelling units (ADUs) by purchasing equity in their properties. In exchange, the homeowner must agree to place a deed restriction on their property in perpetuity to ensure the unit is occupied by .

in perpetuity to ensure the unit is occupied by . ADUs create a wide range of housing options and can increase housing affordability for homeowners and tenants. This bill helps with addressing the housing crisis in Hawaiâ€™i where more than 50% of households spend more than 30% of their income

50% of households spend more than 30% of their income on rent.1 Furthermore, this bill supports community needs within each county. The deed restriction requires the property be occupied by an owner or lessee that works at minimum 30 hrs. at a qualifying business. This ensures that housing stock of

at a qualifying business. This ensures that housing stock of AUDS are made for local workforce in respected areas. Also, prevents homes from being sold to non-resident buyers or used as short-term vacation rentals. The program will preserve affordability for Kamaâ€˜aina and protect property value to ensure it remains attainable

Kamaâ€˜aina and protect property value to ensure it remains attainable and accessible to Hawaiâ€™i residents as primary residences. It seeks to prioritize kamaâ€™aina housing needs and is an investment in local communities, a sustainable economy, and future generations of kamaâ€™aina. This initiative is in line with OHAâ€™s mission to improve

This initiative is in line with OHAâ€™s mission to improve the conditions of Native Hawaiians and ensure their equitable access to housing, education, healthcare, and economic opportunities. It reflects our commitment to advancing the well-being of our beneficiaries and the broader community. OHA appreciates the opportunity to share our manaÊ»o

broader community. OHA appreciates the opportunity to share our manaÊ»o and urges the Legislature to PASS HB740 HD2. Mahalo nui loa. 1 1 University of HawaiÊ»i Economic Research Organization. (2024). HawaiÊ»i housing factbook 2024. Last accessed 030925,https://uhero.hawaii.edu/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/HawaiiHousingFactbook2024.pdf JOSH GREEN M.D. GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. GOVERNOR STATE OF HAWAIâ€˜I DEPARTMENT OF

GOVERNOR SYLVIA LUKE LT. GOVERNOR STATE OF HAWAIâ€˜I DEPARTMENT OF TAXATION Ka â€˜Oihana â€˜Auhau P.O. BOX 259 HONOLULU, HAWAIâ€˜I 96809 PHONE NO: (808) 587-1540 FAX NO: (808) 587-1560 GARY S. SUGANUMA DIRECTOR KRISTEN M.R. SAKAMOTO DEPUTY DIRECTOR TESTIMONY OF GARY S. SUGANUMA, DIRECTOR OF TAXATION TESTIMONY ON THE FOLLOWING MEASURE:

S. SUGANUMA, DIRECTOR OF TAXATION TESTIMONY ON THE FOLLOWING MEASURE: H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2, Relating to Housing. BEFORE THE: Senate Committee on Housing DATE: Tuesday, March 11, 2025 TIME: 1:10 p.m. LOCATION: State Capitol, Room 225 Chair Chang, Vice-Chair Hashimoto, and Members of the Committee: The Department of Taxation

Hashimoto, and Members of the Committee: The Department of Taxation (DOTAX) offers the following comments regarding H.B. 740, H.D. 2, for your consideration. Section 6 of H.B. 740, H.D. 2, amends section 247-3, Hawaii Revised Statutes (HRS), to exempt from conveyance tax any property with a county-owned deed restriction according
conveyance tax any property with a county-owned deed restriction according to the new provisions under chapter 201H, HRS, in this bill. Section 6 also e

SSCR1179 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1179 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 740 H.D. 2 S.D. 1 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Housing, to which was referred H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2, entitled: "A

which was referred H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to establish the Accessory Dwelling Unit Financing and Deed Restriction Program to allocate funds to the counties to provide

Restriction Program to allocate funds to the counties to provide grants to eligible homeowners or homebuyers to finance construction costs, development costs, and non-reoccurring closing costs associated with the construction of an accessory dwelling unit and purchase deed restrictions on such property. Your Committee received testimony in support of this

such property. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation, Office of Hawaiian Affairs, one member of the Maui County Council, Office of Housing of the City and County of Honolulu, Office of Housing and Community Development of the County of

Office of Housing and Community Development of the County of Hawai Ê» i, Hawaii Appleseed Center for Law and Economic Justice, Hawai Ê» i YIMBY, Housing Hawai Ê» i's Future, Hawai Ê» i Children's Action Network Speaks!, Maui Chamber of Commerce, Catholic Charities Hawai Ê» i, Council for Native Hawaiian

Commerce, Catholic Charities Hawai Ê» i, Council for Native Hawaiian Advancement, Save Medicaid Hawaii, Hawai Ê» i Community Foundation, Chamber of Commerce Hawaii, and six individuals. Your Committee received comments on this measure from the Department of Taxation, Hawai Ê» i Association of REALTORS, Holomua Collaborative, and Tax Foundation of

i Association of REALTORS, Holomua Collaborative, and Tax Foundation of Hawaii. Your Committee finds that the State is experiencing a chronic housing shortage. An accessory dwelling unit (ADU) is a small, separate living area that is attached or detached from a primary single-family residence on a single-family lot and is

a primary single-family residence on a single-family lot and is an important type of housing that can efficiently add gentle density to existing, established neighborhoods. While ADUs can help increase the supply of lower-cost housing, there are many financial barriers for homeowners interested in constructing ADUs, including high construction costs,

for homeowners interested in constructing ADUs, including high construction costs, financing challenges, and infrastructure insufficiencies. Incentivizing the construction of ADUs through the deed restriction program established by this measure could help increase housing stock that aligns with specific community needs while ensuring the units constructed are occupied by local workers,

while ensuring the units constructed are occupied by local workers, thereby maintaining employment within the State and preventing the conversion of the units into vacation rentals or investment properties and reducing speculation in the State's housing market. Your Committee notes, however, that the counties already have the authority to implement

however, that the counties already have the authority to implement the ADU and deed restriction program proposed in this measure. Maui County initiated a similar grant program that includes an owner-occupancy requirement, buyback program, and equity sharing. Therefore, the Legislature should study Maui County's deed restriction program before committing additional

should study Maui County's deed restriction program before committing additional state funds for the development of a similar program. Your Committee additionally recognizes the concerns raised by the Office of Housing of the City and County of Honolulu, generally supporting ADUs as an innovative approach to increase housing inventory but

ADUs as an innovative approach to increase housing inventory but noting the County's existing challenges to implement this measure in its current form with regard to capacity, lack of positions and staff, potential impacts to real property tax revenues, eligibility criteria, implementation timelines, enforceability, and potential liability. Your Committee finds

criteria, implementation timelines, enforceability, and potential liability. Your Committee finds that these issues merit further consideration and respectfully requests that these concerns be examined by subsequent Committees that choose to deliberate on this measure as it continues through the legislative process. Your Committee further notes that loans or other forms

process. Your Committee further notes that loans or other forms of investment, rather than a grant program, would allow the State to recover on its investment, thereby enabling the State to finance additional ADUs in the future. For example, the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund Equity Program enables the State to

Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund Equity Program enables the State to share in the capital gain of units receiving state funds. Alternatively, other ways for the State to unlock the value of its investment and maximize future housing construction should be explored. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Changing

explored. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Changing the source of funding from the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund to the Rental Housing Revolving Fund; (2) Changing the Accessory Dwelling Unit Financing and Deed Restriction Program from a grant program to an equity purchase program; (3) Clarifying that the

program to an equity purchase program; (3) Clarifying that the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) may allocate a dollar amount necessary for a county to carry out the program; provided that the total contribution amount from a county distributed per accessory dwelling unit shall not exceed eight percent
distributed per accessory dwelling unit shall not exceed eight percent of the appraised value of the property; (4) Specifying that HHFDC shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 per year for the

SSCR1179 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1179 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 740 H.D. 2 S.D. 1 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Housing, to which was referred H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2, entitled: "A

which was referred H.B. No. 740, H.D. 2, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO HOUSING," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to establish the Accessory Dwelling Unit Financing and Deed Restriction Program to allocate funds to the counties to provide

Restriction Program to allocate funds to the counties to provide grants to eligible homeowners or homebuyers to finance construction costs, development costs, and non-reoccurring closing costs associated with the construction of an accessory dwelling unit and purchase deed restrictions on such property. Your Committee received testimony in support of this

such property. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation, Office of Hawaiian Affairs, one member of the Maui County Council, Office of Housing of the City and County of Honolulu, Office of Housing and Community Development of the County of

Office of Housing and Community Development of the County of Hawai Ê» i, Hawaii Appleseed Center for Law and Economic Justice, Hawai Ê» i YIMBY, Housing Hawai Ê» i's Future, Hawai Ê» i Children's Action Network Speaks!, Maui Chamber of Commerce, Catholic Charities Hawai Ê» i, Council for Native Hawaiian

Commerce, Catholic Charities Hawai Ê» i, Council for Native Hawaiian Advancement, Save Medicaid Hawaii, Hawai Ê» i Community Foundation, Chamber of Commerce Hawaii, and six individuals. Your Committee received comments on this measure from the Department of Taxation, Hawai Ê» i Association of REALTORS, Holomua Collaborative, and Tax Foundation of

i Association of REALTORS, Holomua Collaborative, and Tax Foundation of Hawaii. Your Committee finds that the State is experiencing a chronic housing shortage. An accessory dwelling unit (ADU) is a small, separate living area that is attached or detached from a primary single-family residence on a single-family lot and is

a primary single-family residence on a single-family lot and is an important type of housing that can efficiently add gentle density to existing, established neighborhoods. While ADUs can help increase the supply of lower-cost housing, there are many financial barriers for homeowners interested in constructing ADUs, including high construction costs,

for homeowners interested in constructing ADUs, including high construction costs, financing challenges, and infrastructure insufficiencies. Incentivizing the construction of ADUs through the deed restriction program established by this measure could help increase housing stock that aligns with specific community needs while ensuring the units constructed are occupied by local workers,

while ensuring the units constructed are occupied by local workers, thereby maintaining employment within the State and preventing the conversion of the units into vacation rentals or investment properties and reducing speculation in the State's housing market. Your Committee notes, however, that the counties already have the authority to implement

however, that the counties already have the authority to implement the ADU and deed restriction program proposed in this measure. Maui County initiated a similar grant program that includes an owner-occupancy requirement, buyback program, and equity sharing. Therefore, the Legislature should study Maui County's deed restriction program before committing additional

should study Maui County's deed restriction program before committing additional state funds for the development of a similar program. Your Committee additionally recognizes the concerns raised by the Office of Housing of the City and County of Honolulu, generally supporting ADUs as an innovative approach to increase housing inventory but

ADUs as an innovative approach to increase housing inventory but noting the County's existing challenges to implement this measure in its current form with regard to capacity, lack of positions and staff, potential impacts to real property tax revenues, eligibility criteria, implementation timelines, enforceability, and potential liability. Your Committee finds

criteria, implementation timelines, enforceability, and potential liability. Your Committee finds that these issues merit further consideration and respectfully requests that these concerns be examined by subsequent Committees that choose to deliberate on this measure as it continues through the legislative process. process. Your Committee further notes that loans or other forms of investment, rather than a grant program, would allow the State to recover on its investment, thereby enabling the State to finance additional ADUs in the future. For example, the Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund Equity Program enables the State to

Dwelling Unit Revolving Fund Equity Program enables the State to share in the capital gain of units receiving state funds. Alternatively, other ways for the State to unlock the value of its investment and maximize future housing construction should be explored. Your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Changing

explored. program to an equity purchase program; (3) Clarifying that the Hawaii Housing Finance and Development Corporation (HHFDC) may allocate a dollar amount necessary for a county to carry out the program; provided that the total contribution amount from a county distributed per accessory dwelling unit shall not exceed eight percent
distributed per accessory dwelling unit shall not exceed eight percent of the appraised value of the property; (4) Specifying that HHFDC shall not allocate more than $2,000,000 per year for the
